entries: Though the Keleres carry out missions on behalf of the Galactic Council and the galaxy as a whole, they have their own goals and missions they wish to achieve as well. Agendas are personal missions that, though they may also be in service to a political faction or dynasty, deepen the story of each individual player character and introduce drama, conflict, and dilemmas to the campaign. Agendas combine rules, roleplaying, and storytelling in a way that empowers players to advance the narrative alongside their GM.

While the story moves forward in interesting and unexpected ways, characters earn experience and resources to reward their participation in their own agendas. These rewards not only benefit the individual characters whose agenda advanced but also the other characters who may have had to sacrifice some of their own time and resources to help their ally move forward.

entries.title: Elements of an Agenda
entries: Agendas in Twilight Imperium reflect certain mechanical and story elements. The key elements of each agenda are as follows:

items: An agenda is a long-term goal that requires much work and effort on the part of characters to achieve.
An agenda must be story-driven and centered around one of the player characters, not centered around the main plot of the campaign.
Advancing a character's agenda must involve some risk and chance of failure but also a chance for reward.
Advancing a character's agenda must, at times, force them to make decisions that put other characters or goals at risk.
Each agenda has a series of benchmarks that must be accomplished before the agenda can be completed. The number of benchmarks and how they can be completed depends on the agenda and the character.

entries: Whether you are using an agenda listed in {@table 1-3: Embers of the Imperium Agendas}, adopting one of the agendas specific to the various Great Civilizations, or creating your own, it is important to include all of these elements.

rule.name: Selecting an Agenda
description: At character creation, select an agenda for your character by either rolling for or selecting an option in {@table 1-3: Embers of the Imperium Agendas}. In addition, each of the Great Civilizations also has unique agendas you may select for your character. Each option has a name, short description, and example benchmarks. When selecting an agenda, simply write its name in the space provided on your character sheet, and work with your GM to determine the details of the agenda for your character.

For example, your character may have Knowledge as an agenda. Knowledge could mean anything from ingratiating oneself with an enemy faction to understand it, to gaining access to a well-guarded repository of knowledge on behalf of the Great Civilization you serve. Whatever the case, every agenda should be both epic and personal to the character who selects it and in line with that character's personality and allegiance.

description.title: Public or Secret Agendas
entries: The agenda of each character should be hidden from each other character. However, whether agendas are hidden from the other {@i players} is up to your group.

If your group prefers, the agenda of each character can be hidden, known only to the controlling player and GM until it is revealed over the course of the game. This can create more realistic scheming and infighting among the group, but the whole group should be careful not to let this get out of hand and engender ill feelings between players if one character ends up betraying another.

The second option is to have the agendas be public knowledge among the players, but to have everyone play their character as if they don't know the other members' agendas. If your group members are good at compartmentalizing metaknowledge and like to collaboratively create tense and dramatic situations for their characters, this option may be the better choice.

rule.name: Advancing Agendas
description: As a game progresses, your character has multiple chances to advance and eventually complete their agenda. They do this by accomplishing benchmarks. Once a certain number of benchmarks have been completed, you and your GM devise a side mission for your character to undertake to resolve their agenda. If they resolve their agenda successfully, they receive a reward.

entries.title: Benchmarks
entries: Every agenda has a set number of benchmarks that must be completed for it to have a chance of being resolved. What these benchmarks are will largely be up to you, with some help from your GM.

During game sessions, you may notice an opportunity within the ongoing story that you think is an appropriate benchmark for your character's agenda. This does not have to be something the GM has specifically written into their story, and it may involve you inventing some additional story elements that can be woven into the ongoing narrative.

If you notice one of these opportunities, then once per session you can (publicly or privately) propose to the GM that this opportunity may be a good benchmark for your character's agenda. If your GM agrees, then your character can take the opportunity, engaging in whatever actions are necessary to accomplish it successfully.

However, sometimes an opportunity could derail the ongoing story or otherwise work against your GM's plans. Your GM always has the final say on whether an opportunity can become a benchmark for your character's agenda. However, if they reject your proposal, they must move a Story Point from the GM pool to the player pool (as long as there is a Story Point in the GM pool to move).

entries.title: Number of Benchmarks in an Agenda
entries: All character agendas have a set number of benchmarks to be completed. However, you can increase the number of benchmarks your character needs to complete in order to give your character additional gear or starting experience.

{@b Each agenda must have a minimum of four completed benchmarks before it can potentially be resolved.} If your character fails to complete a benchmark, this does not count against them. They must just find another opportunity to complete a benchmark later in the campaign.

However, when you create your character, you can increase the number of benchmarks they must accomplish in exchange for gaining benefits during character creation. You can choose one of the following options:

items: You can give your character an additional 10 starting experience. If you do so, increase the number of required benchmarks by 1.
You can give your character an additional 1,000 aurei to spend on starting gear. If you do so, increase the number of required benchmarks by 1.
You can give your character an additional 10 starting experience and 500 aurei to spend on starting gear. If you do so, increase the number of required benchmarks by 2.

entries.title: Side Missions and Completing Agendas
entries: Once your character has completed the necessary number of benchmarks, you should consult with your GM about a side mission for your character that, if completed successfully, resolves their agenda once and for all.

The side mission depends on what your character's agenda is. For someone with a personal agenda, like Revenge, the mission may involve finally tracking down a hated foe and defeating them. An agenda of Resourcefulness may see your character taking saved money to pay off a sibling's ransom, or needing to seek out a questionable money launderer to exchange aurei for untraceable assets that can let them start a new life of luxury.

Some agendas, especially those involving greater themes such as liberty, supporting a particular faction, or working to advance the mission of the Keleres, may not be "completed" just because your character finishes their side mission successfully. In these cases, the side mission can represent your character doing what they feel they need to do to promote their chosen cause. An agenda supporting one of the Great Civilizations may take the form of "one last job" that, if accomplished, gives that particular galactic power some crucial edge in the ongoing conflict for the Imperial Throne. Alternatively, defeating a Nekro assassin's attempt to poison the Galactic Council may not stop the Nekro from making attempts in the future, but it certainly can be enough for your character to feel like they've done their part.

It's up to your GM whether the side mission just involves your character or the whole group. However, we do recommend getting the whole group involved, even if your character has to awkwardly reveal their agenda after a long campaign. Most of the time, it's a lot more fun!

entries.title: Rewarding Agenda Completion
entries: When your character successfully completes an agenda, they earn a reward. Some elements of the reward may be narrative: saving a sibling, supporting a cause, or finding absolution for past misdeeds. Others may be material, such as command of a warship, discovery of an ancient and valuable artifact, or simply acquisition of a huge amount of aurei in untraceable accounts.
Your GM determines the reward, although you can certainly suggest possibilities to them. The following are some baseline rewards, and your GM can invent something else if they like.

items: {@b 75 XP:} This is a good reward to pair with a narrative agenda reward. Your character grows and improves in the course of accomplishing their goals.
{@b 250,000 aurei:} Money may not buy happiness, but it can certainly buy a lot of luxuries for your character.
{@b An artifact:} See pages 131 to 133 for a list of potential relics that could make interesting rewards.
{@b An FTL-capable starship your character can operate:} Whether a tramp freighter, a sleek starfighter, or a fast courier vessel, an FTL-capable ship gives them the freedom to go where they want.

{@b Command of a warship, and a detached duty assignment:} Your character gets to captain a warship such as a destroyer or cruiser. Its power is at their disposal, and they have been given the authority to use it during their own adventures.

{@b A position of authority:} A governorship of a small colony, a high-level position in a powerful organization, or the chance to become one of the Tribunii in the Keleres—each offers a character the chance to wield great influence, or even to retire from adventuring if they like.

entries: In addition, whenever a character completes their agenda successfully, all other characters in the group earn an additional 15 XP (in addition to whatever they normally earn for regular gameplay). This represents the experience the other characters earn from working to help their fellow Keleres complete their agenda (or from working to hinder it). It also offers a reward to the players for allowing the campaign to be briefly sidetracked.

entries.title: Next Steps
entries: Once your character has completed their agenda, you and your GM need to decide what happens to them next. In most cases, your character may continue in the campaign without an agenda. The default gameplay experience assumes each character will only have a single agenda over the course of a campaign.
However, your GM may decide to work with you to give your character a new agenda. This is especially appropriate in longer campaigns, and once everyone has had a chance to complete their own agenda.

Finally, in some cases you and your GM may decide the completion of an agenda is a chance to retire a character and make a new one. Your old character may even become a prominent NPC for the group, either a valuable ally or a dangerous enemy, depending on what their agenda was.

rule.name: Factions and Allegiance
description: An integral aspect of making a character in {@title Embers of the Imperium} is deciding on your relationship to the Great Civilizations. But for the few independent worlds in the galaxy, most worlds belong to one or another of the Great Civilizations. These systems drift through the void, not in well-defined territories but rather in diffuse confederations, intermingling and without clear borders. In whatever part of the galaxy your character was raised, there is likely some representation from each of the Great Civilizations.

When selecting an allegiance to one of the Great Civilizations for your character, think of how that civilization shapes the character's ideals, goals, and fears. Each Great Civilization has something at stake in the future of galactic civilization: something to gain and something to lose. Each civilization relates to the others in a unique way as well. Understanding these relationships and specifying how your character reflects them (or doesn't) makes the setting and your character more realistic. Read the description of the Great Civilizations later in this chapter, and keep these factors in mind as you write your story.

description.title: Inventing your own Allegiance
entries: While your allegiance may help you pick your character's agenda, allegiance is primarily a roleplaying prompt. You don't have to select one of the following factions for your allegiance and can instead invent your own. This could be to a criminal organization, a mercantile conglomerate, your character's extended family, or even the Keleres.

description: {@filter rule|Factions in Embers of the Imperium|source:embers-of-the-imperium=1;category:great civilization=1}

rule.name: Pay
description: As members of a government organization, the Keleres do get compensation for their work. This amount is kept deliberately low, to reinforce the core game concept that the Keleres are underpaid and underappreciated. However, how low this amount is depends on just how desperate you want to keep your players' characters

We have three suggested amounts, each paid four times per Mecatol year. This means that you can choose to track time in your game to make payments, or issue them at the end of a campaign arc (which, depending on travel times, you can claim has taken roughly three months).

items: {@b 500 aurei:} This amount is set almost comically low to encourage players to have their characters engage in all sorts of graft, corruption, and side deals. Without bending the law, PCs will have a hard time affording more than basic weapons and equipment or will be totally reliant on what the quartermasters give them.

{@b 1,000 aurei:} This is an "average" amount that means your PCs will be able to upgrade their equipment after each adventure, but won't be able to obtain heavy weapons or rare items without scrimping and saving. The PCs won't need to engage in illicit activities, but there may be some temptation to do so.

{@b 2,500 aurei:} This payment level is appropriate if you want your group to be well-paid and not worrying about money. With this amount, the only things that will be out of reach after a couple of sessions are starships and vehicles. However, you will want to give your PCs corresponding challenges to match their powerful gear.

description: This payment system assumes that your PCs' cost of living expenses are being maintained by the Keleres. They are given rooms in the Keleres HQ, receive meals from the mess hall, and have any basic medical care covered by the infirmary.

description.title: The Keleres Armory and Issued Supplies
entries: This payment system also does not account for gear the Keleres may receive from the official supply depots and base armory to accomplish their missions. The Winnaran Custodians responsible for supplies are notoriously stingy with the meager resources allocated to the Keleres, but a cohort can still expect some support, especially if they are friends with one of the quartermasters.

Your players are likely to think of asking for items from the armory, and if they don't, you can suggest this as an option. The important thing is for them to use the armory to obtain basic supplies, and not try to argue that each of them needs a personal beam cannon and force field for every mission. To help with this, we have some guidelines for what your group can request from the armory.

items: Requests should only happen before an authorized mission. Quartermasters are likely to deny any random requests out of hand.
The cohort makes requests as a group. Before a mission, the cohort may request a number of items with a combined value of no greater than 500 aurei. No item can have a rarity greater than 3.

Any items that aren't single use or consumable (such as grenades, z-tabs, extra ammunition, or dermal sealers) need to be returned to the armory at the end of the mission. Failure to return items should result in the quartermasters significantly limiting the next request the group makes or denying it entirely.

entries: The important thing to remember is that the Winnaran quartermasters have wide discretion in what requests they honor and what requests they don't. Although it may not seem fair, cohorts that make friends with a quartermaster have a much better chance of getting greater requests met. Conversely, those who anger a quartermaster are likely to see their requests denied entirely

Some of this can be handled through roleplaying. If you feel like your group has successfully gotten on a quartermaster's good side, you can increase the amount of gear they're allowed to requisition, up to 1,000 aurei. The other option is if a PC wants to obtain an item that is either rarer or more expensive than the normal requisition rules allow. In this case, you can have the PC make a {@skill Charm||crb} or {@skill Negotiation||crb} check with a difficulty determined by {@table I.5-1: Rarity||crb} on page 82 of the Core Rulebook to see if they can convince the quartermaster to let them requisition the item. Of course, it is ultimately up to you whether the armory has the item in stock. Don't feel that you have to give your group a sliver missile launcher just because they rolled well!

setting.name: Twilight Imperium
summary: See {@title Twilight Imperium: Embers of the Imperium} for more information on the Twilight Imperium setting.

entries: A cohort of Keleres may have uncovered a plot by the Barony of Letnev to undermine the Galactic Council and take territory from the Federation of Sol. The three Keleres—Ccroagok, Alina Vorn, and Alexi—are all working to stop the Barony's plot, but each also has their own goal. Ccroagok seeks forgiveness for the transgressions of his youth, Alina Vorn wants to pursue a seat on the Galactic Council herself, and Alexi sends blackmail payments to ensure that evidence of a crime his brother committed aren't leaked by a crime syndicate. Though none of these agendas are exclusive to stopping the Barony, they can still force the group to make difficult decisions.

Over the course of the game, Alina networks with potential allies and forges political alliances, while Ccroagok performs missions for the family he attacked seventeen years prior as a way of atoning. However, Alexi makes the difficult decision to stick to exposing the Barony rather than obtaining money to make his blackmail payments. In the end, the syndicate reveals the criminal information and his brother is arrested, but he successfully halts a war that could have seen hundreds of thousands dead.

sidebar.name: Agendas and Your Campaign
description: Agendas add complexity to the larger story of an Embers of the Imperium game. However, they also contribute a sense of realism, integrating each character into the setting. Keeping this in mind, it's important to think about how you plan for each agenda to develop in the campaign plot.
Agendas can use NPCs as side antagonists, incorporate a character's goals into the greater story, or give the player characters a short adventure outside of the main plot.

You can use agendas to help plan your sessions by focusing on one PC's agenda one session, another's the next, and so on. Not every session need be devoted to an agenda, however; nor do all sessions that focus on an agenda need to ignore the main plot.

entries: During a stealth mission on a trade station orbiting Jord, Alina Vorn is sneaking through the offices of the Federation of Sol's Naval Intelligence division. Her player, Rex, thinks that if Alina can break into one of the computer terminals, she may be able to get information on her political rivals that could increase her chances of being appointed to the Galactic Council. Rex proposes this as a benchmark to his GM, Lex.

Lex considers the proposal and agrees, but warns Rex that if Alina tries to break into the terminal,it could set off alarms and hinder her chances of completing the stealth mission. Rex decides that Alina is happy to take that chance, and she accesses the terminal. She successfully retrieves information about a rival taking bribes, which means she has accomplished a benchmark. However, she also sets off an alarm, and the authorities dispatch guards to hunt down Alina and her fellow Keleres.

sidebar.name: FTL Speeds and Travel Distances
description: Travel in the galaxy, even at superluminal speeds, can take a long time. That's because the galaxy is huge beyond comprehension. Almost no ship has the range to get from one side of the galaxy to the other, but FTL mass-drives still make an interstellar empire a possibility.

For game purposes, the speed a ship can reach in FTL travel, and the distance it can traverse before needing to refuel (its "range"), are kept as a few broad, abstract categories. These should usually be sufficient to keep the game moving. The categories are listed in {@table 3-1: FTL Speeds} and {@table 3-1: FTL Ranges}, along with some examples.

sidebar.name: Knockdown and Vehicles
description: The {@quality Knockdown||crb} quality can be used to affect vehicles. For mechs, this works the same as any character being knocked down. The mech is knocked prone, its speed drops to 0, and it can't move until the pilot performs a move maneuver to get it to stand.

For other vehicles, being knocked down may represent being rolled, flipped, jammed into terrain where it can't move, or in the case of flying vehicles, knocked into an uncontrollable tailspin. In these cases, the vehicle's speed is reduced to 0 and it can't move until the pilot makes a successful {@difficulty Hard|Piloting or Driving}. If the vehicle flies, the pilot may only have a certain amount of time to get it moving before it crashes into the ground.

sidebar.name: Mahact Sleeper Agents and Enslaved Vassals
description: The agents of the {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} are legion, despite the long millennia of their absence. Some of the {@rule Mahact gene-sorcerers|Mahact gene-sorcerers'} sleeper agents were literally sent into dormancy for thousands of years, most notably the {@rule Titans of Ul}. Though the {@rule Titans of Ul|Titans} overthrew their former masters' domination upon their awakening, the {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} have other agents who awoke when they returned, agents who are still loyal and ready to serve.

However, the {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} also have more insidious means of infiltrating a population. They seeded most of the intelligent species of the galaxy with cunning genetic code that would lie dormant through countless generations, passed from parent to child. Many variants of that code would become corrupt and useless, but in some cases, it would remain true. When triggered with certain {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} devices, the code turns the individual who bears it into a loyal {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} puppet, outwardly unchanged but unable to resist their commands.

Likewise, the {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact's} ships and armies contain many vassals who have either pledged themselves to the service of the {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|gene-sorcerers} or who have had their loyalty enforced through genetic modification.

Any of the profiles listed here (except for the Nekro and Titan profiles) can be used as a {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} sleeper agent or enslaved vassal. They retain all of their normal abilities, and their forced loyalty can be handled narratively. In fact, {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact} ships are often crewed by a mix of enslaved vassals from a number of cultures, so you can use a mix of different profiles when determining the crew.

sidebar.name: NPC Crews
description: Ships and vehicles need crew to operate, and if they're not being operated by the party, they'll need a crew of NPCs. Various NPC profiles appropriate for crew can be found in Chapter 6. Profiles for military crews can be found in the {@b Soldiers of the Great Civilizations} section starting on page 248, while profiles for vessels of the Great Threats can be found in the {@b Agents of the Great Threats} section starting on page 255.

sidebar.name: Restricted (R) Items
description: Some of the items in this book have an "R" next to their cost, indicating that they are restricted. Although every society tends to have its own laws about what is illegal and what isn't, some weapons and items are generally considered dangerous or reprehensible enough to be limited to military personnel, or banned entirely. Restricted items tend to be illegal for civilians to possess on most civilized planets. Although the {@rule the keleres of the council|Keleres} are technically exempt from these limitations because of their status as agents of {@rule the Galactic Council}, they can expect some harassment or pushback from local law enforcement or planetary officials if they carry restricted items openly in public. At the very least, it will likely get them noticed.

sidebar.name: Sensor Ranges
description: Nearly every ship and vehicle has some sort of passive and active sensors, from the simple proximity sensors on a carrum to the massive sweep arrays aboard a dreadnought. For the most part, these sensors serve a narrative purpose, allowing characters to "see" in the depths of space out beyond range of their eyes. However, if the GM needs to determine an effective range for sensors, they can use the following guidelines:

Passive sensors can be used out to strategic range. They have no problem detecting a ship that is not making an effort to hide (such as a ship with its engines running, or one that has its own active sensors going). If, at the GM's discretion, another ship or other object is making some effort to go unnoticed (such as keeping its engines off or using sensor baffles), then the operator must make a {@skill Vigilance||crb} check with a difficulty set by the GM to detect the target.
Active sensors can be used out to long range. They always require a {@skill Perception||crb} check to use, with a difficulty set by the GM to detect the target depending on how well hidden it is.

skill.name: Knowledge (Culture)
description: This skill governs all knowledge of the myriad societies and species that populate the galaxy. This includes basic information on the motivations of various factions and Great Civilizations, the patterns and markets of galactic trade, and common knowledge about various species. This is the skill your character should use if they want to know what is going on in the galaxy today.
shouldUse: Your character wants to know why two Great Civilizations are hostile toward each other.
Your character wants to know how valuable a shipment of menn root is on a specific world.
Your character needs to remember the proper etiquette when meeting with a dignitary from the {@rule Embers of Muaat}.
Your character is looking for a particular planet with a thriving black-market trade in stolen artifacts.
shouldNotUse: Your character needs to make small talk with a diplomatic dignitary. That would require {@skill Charm||crb}.
Your character is trying to track down an artifact smuggler after arriving on a particular world. This would require {@skill Streetwise||crb}.
Your character is trying to recall information about a particular species' biology, which is something they would need to be versed in {@skill Knowledge (Science)} to know about.

skill.name: Knowledge (Lore)
description: The galaxy has a long and storied history, and much of the ancient past has been relegated to myth and legend. Historians have their hands full cataloging even recent history, but as the resurgence of the {@rule L1Z1X Mindnet|L1Z1X} and {@rule Mahact gene-sorcerers} proves, what happened in the past matters in the present. The Lore skill oversees all knowledge of the galaxy's history: fact, legend, and the blurry border between them.
shouldUse: Your character wants to know if a set of ruins was built by the {@rule Mahact Gene-Sorcerers|Mahact}, the Lazax, or an even older culture.
Your character is trying to recall the history of humanity's colonization of the stars, and how that species spread so far throughout the galaxy.
Your character wants to know the older names of {@rule Jord}, the homeworld of humanity, and of the {@rule Federation of Sol}.
Your character is researching ancient sightings of {@rule Empyrean} ships.
shouldNotUse: Your character needs to open an ancient tomb door without activating a defense system. That requires {@skill Skulduggery||crb}.
Your character is trying to figure out the functions of an L1Z1X's cybernetic implants. This would be a {@skill Knowledge (Science)} check.
Your character is trying to fight a {@adversary Mahact thrall clone}. Your character should be using a combat skill instead.

skill.name: Knowledge (Science)
description: Although many sciences have evolved tremendously over thousands of years, the basic scientific principles remain the same. The Science skill covers the myriad scientific disciplines, from biology to structural materials to theoretical astrophysics to multidimensional theory. Characters who are highly educated, especially in any technical fields, tend to have more ranks in the Science skill.
shouldUse: Your character is trying to figure out how an unknown piece of technology from an alien species works.
Your character is trying to remember specific aspects of a species' biology.
Your character wants to know about the biosphere of a particular world.
Your character needs to know how long they have before a star goes supernova.
shouldNotUse: Your character is trying to decipher the writings on an ancient crypt world. That requires {@skill Knowledge (Lore)}.
Your character wants to calculate a route for their starship to take. This requires the {@skill Astrocartography||crb skill.
Your character is trying to repair a ship's mass-drive. Understanding the drive's principles may require Science, but your character needs to use {@skill Mechanics||crb} to fix or modify it.

table.name: Table 1-3: Embers of the Imperium Agendas

rows.type: {@b Ascension:} Among the political, social, and military hierarchies of the galaxy, Keleres operatives have much to gain if recognized for meritorious behavior and if they cultivate important connections. A Keleres operative with the Ascension agenda seeks to climb through the ranks of one of these hierarchies and make a name for themself, if not within their allegiance, then in the galaxy as a whole.
benchmarks: Receive a promotion to a higher rank or office.
Sabotage the career of a rival to ensure they don't get in your way.
Receive recognition or an award for performing your duties well.

rows.type: {@b Revenge:} The galaxy is a dynamo of contentious relationships between individuals, groups they have allegiance to, and other factions. It is no wonder, then, that Keleres operatives are often caught up in events beyond their control and fall victim to the machinations of others. Keleres operatives with the Revenge agenda seek to strike back at an individual or organization that wronged them in the past.
benchmarks: Identify a weakness that your enemy possesses.
Turn a member of the enemy organization so that they are secretly working for you.
Convince others to help you in your quest for revenge.

rows.type: {@b Knowledge:} The galaxy is a vast and dangerous place with many secrets. Secret societies, government plots, and lost artifacts lie beneath the dermis of the galaxy, waiting to be uncovered. Keleres operatives with the Knowledge agenda are hungry to uncover rare, dangerous, and empowering secrets.
benchmarks: Learn a valuable piece of information nobody else has.
Discover a lost artifact and ensure you can keep it for yourself.
Conduct a dangerous experiment on the artifact.

rows.type: {@b Absolution:} Many a galactic citizen faces difficult choices or transitions to a new way of life as the wisdom of age replaces the folly of youth. Keleres operatives with the Absolution agenda committed a wrong in the past that they now wish to atone for. The process of atonement is a long and difficult path toward expiating what cannot be undone.
benchmarks: Locate the person or organization you wronged in the past, and learn as much as you can about them.
Provide a service (such as helping accomplish a goal, sending money, or offering unrequested aid) to the person or organization you owe amends to.
Take concrete steps to improve your life and be a better person.

rows.type: {@b Liberty:} Slavery, oppression, and the effects of changing sovereignty flourish among the worlds of the galaxy—and with these things come nascent revolution. Keleres operatives with the Liberty agenda stop at nothing to neutralize the tyranny holding them down.
benchmarks: Free someone who is enthralled or enslaved.
Identify an organization that participates in upholding or enforcing slavery or servitude.
Take an action that harms the organization's ability to continue its oppression.

rows.type: {@b Devotion:} As the Great Civilizations struggle with one another, their peoples become enamored of the meaning and history behind the power they fight for. Though the Keleres is nominally an intragalactic organization, those among its ranks rarely forget where they came from. A Keleres operative with the Devotion agenda is firmly rooted in their family, nation, or allegiance in a way that sets them apart from others. They strive to make a name not for themself but to advance the history of the greater faction they are a part of.
benchmarks: Learn valuable information and send it to your superiors in the faction you are loyal to.
Perform a task you think will help your faction further its goals.
Sabotage a mission that would have aided another faction, particularly one that is working in opposition to your faction.

rows.type: {@b Resourcefulness:} A sibling sends money home to keep her brother off the streets; a soldier saves his income so that he may escape the poverty that plagued his family for generations; a spouse slowly gathers funds to pay off a ransom. Keleres operatives with the Resourcefulness agenda have some need or debt that not only keeps them from living a comfortable life but helps determine the actions they take. Their resourcefulness is less a talent or a blessing than a necessity in the face of the galaxy's many hardships.
benchmarks: Send or save a large payment of 1,000 aurei or more.

Identify a means by which you can end this agenda rather than continuing to pay. This means could be something like freeing a ransomed family member, finding a job for a troubled sibling, or performing one last massive job in order to get enough money for retirement.

aesthetics: Use seemingly arcane technology to craft exquisitely shaped items of gold or white metals.
Inlaid with intricately carved neon-blue or neon-green gemstones.
Each piece is a unique sculpture of otherworldly curves and flexible alloy piping.
Mimicking {@rule Naalu Collective|Druaa} strengths, items use crystal weave technology to portray elegance and mystery.
Smooth-sided angles form sharp points for a triangular appearance, with weblike materials between.
Edges inlaid with brown or green gel sacks provide comfort to the user.

mods: Rarity +4, non-Empyrean my not use these items without a savant with a broadcast link to the item (all)
aesthetics: Appear to be pieces of bronze metal worked into a variety of shapes, with little adornment or decoration.
Are pitted and scarred from long-term vacuum exposure and look to be many millennia old.
Internal mechanisms controlled by radio-wave broadcasts from the Empyrean wielder. No external controls.
Flexible bronzed piping interconnected with heavy carbon-scored curved metal plating in a durable design.
Marked with bold, chiseled iconography.
Capable of withstanding extreme temperatures.
Most weapons utilize intense heat to deal damage.
Crafted with a philosophy of high quality over mass-produced mediocrity.
Expertly crafted to include carved woods, fine silks, and gold filigree etched or woven into the materials.
Red or blue opal paneling.
Rugged, simple, and guaranteed to survive.
Constructed using drab, gray metals with additional protrusions for attachments.
Appear inexpensive and mass-produced.
Technologically advanced with little care for elegance.
Focus on pushing technology to its limits.
Most items include onboard savants and other computational devices to aid the user.
Galvanized steel predominates appearance; accentuated with brass or copper highlights.

rows.mods: Base damage +2 and add {@quality Slow-Firing|Slow-Firing 1|crb} (ranged weapons)
aesthetics: Constructed with lots of exposed circuits, wires, and plates of gray metal.
Most items are designed to be integrated directly into the user's body.
Glowing yellow energy vents and micro-reactors.
Adorned with smooth lines and regal finishes, and engineered to evoke confidence, discipline, and fearlessness.
Gold predominates designs, particularly those of armor.
Polished metal finishes mixed with blue, red, and yellow fabrics.
{@rule Mentak Coalition|Coalition} items bear resemblance to multiple different cultural crafting practices.
Many items appear jury-rigged or as if they've been repaired multiple times.
Rugged simplicity tends to be a default design aesthetic.

rows.mods: Reduce Critical rating by 1, to a minimum of 2, and add {@quality Unwieldy||crb} +2 (weapons).
aesthetics: Item housings tend to be sculpted out of press-formed silicates that mimic a carapace.
Colors tend to seem dull or muted but appear bright and vibrant to eyes that can see in the lower UV spectra.
Designs are awkward for noninsectoids.

mods: When making a check with item, must spend {@symbols hhh} or {@symbols d} to damage item one step (see {@rule Item Maintenance||crb} on page 89 of the Core Rulebook) (all)
aesthetics: Almost all devices are powered, usually containing a small, green, glowing microbattery or reactor.
Items tend to evince a "brute-force" approach to design, often being overpowered but fragile.
Products tend to be cobbled together from limited resources and reflect sturdy and mechanically sound construction.
Items with exposed innards and haphazardly bolted-on or welded-on attachments seem unconventional but demonstrate harmony amid chaos.
Cosmetic designs often feature sweeping, stylized wings and gliding shapes that evoke flight and freedom.
Highly flexible ablative armors display a mix of grays and natural colors.

mods: Base damage +2 and price +250 (Brawl and Melee weapons)
aesthetics: The sheer size of Titan gear often makes its use impractical for all but Titans.
Covered in polished-silver metallic plates and powered by stylized orange, red, and purple power crystals.
Large, dazzling agates and gold chains harken back to the uniforms and outfits of the old Lazax.
Gold or silver adorns many products.
Clothing comes in an eclectic mix of browns, greens, and yellows.
Crafted with triple redundancies and extreme durability.
Onboard diagnostic tools allow for easier repairs but often increase the size of the apparatus.
No color standards exist except for members of religious sects, who wear browns and reds in patterns and shades unique for their own sect.
Use lots of browns and yellows in their color scheme.
Locally built items include religious iconography worked into the design.
Many items are purchased from off-world and appear generic.
Although their designs may appear low-tech, {@rule Yssaril Tribes|Yssaril} engineers develop some of the most feared weapons and covert equipment in the galaxy.
Embracing their ancient heritages, they rely on transmorphic materials and genetically engineered animal products to hide their advancements behind a facade of archaic technology reliance.

rows.examples: A nearby star system only a few dozen lightyears away. Only able to travel for a day or less at FTL before needing to refuel.
Anywhere within the borders of most of the Great Civilizations; a few hundred light-years from a well-established spaceport. Able to travel for weeks at FTL without refueling.
To {@rule Mecatol Rex} from the edge of the galaxy; thousands of light-years from home. Able to travel for months at FTL without refueling.
From the edge of one spiral arm to another; tens of thousands of light-years or more. Able to travel for over a year at FTL without refueling.
Takes a week to get to a nearby star system, several weeks to cross a single civilizations' territory, months to reach {@rule Mecatol Rex}, and many years to cross the galaxy.

Takes a couple of days to reach a nearby star system, a week to go from one end of a single civilization's territory to the other, a month or less to reach {@rule Mecatol Rex}, and six months to a year to cross the galaxy.
Takes less than a day to reach a nearby star system, a couple of days to cross a civilization's territory, a couple of weeks to reach {@rule Mecatol Rex}, and a couple of months to cross the galaxy.
Takes a few hours to reach a nearby star system, no more than two days to cross a civilization's territory, a week or so to reach {@rule Mecatol Rex}, and a month or so to cross the galaxy.
A common FTL trade route between two systems within short range of each other (see {@table 3-1: FTL Ranges}).

A destination that is within short distance, but with a badly mapped route that is infrequently traveled; a destination within medium or long range that is along a route on a common travel corridor (see {@table 3-1: FTL Ranges}).
Any route through uncharted space, or any route to a destination that is at extreme range (see {@table 3-1: FTL Ranges}).

talent.name: Basic Combat Training
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Brawl||crb}, {@skill Ranged (Heavy)||crb}, or {@skill Ranged (Light)||crb} as a career skill.

talent.name: Cosmopolitan Upbringing
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Streetwise||crb} or {@skill Knowledge (Culture)} as a career skill. In addition, when using one of these skills to resolve a conflict between members of different species, your character may spend {@symbols aa} to heal 3 strain.

talent.name: Data Miner
description: Once per session before making a knowledge skill check, your character may use this talent to use the {@skill Computers||crb} skill to make the check instead of a knowledge skill.

talent.name: Diplomatic Instruction
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Leadership||crb} or {@skill Negotiation||crb} as a career skill. In addition, when using one of these skills to convince their allies to undertake a particular task in a social encounter, your character may spend {@symbols aa} to heal 3 strain.

talent.name: Emergency Thruster Burn
description: Once per round while controlling a starship that requires the {@skill Operating||crb} skill to direct, your character may use this talent to increase or decrease its speed by 1, to a minimum of 0 or a maximum of the starship's max speed. The starship suffers 2 system strain.

talent.name: Emergency Vacuum Training
description: Your character does not count zero-gravity environments as {@rule difficult and impassable terrain|difficult terrain|crb}. When your character is exposed to {@rule vacuum||crb} without protective gear, they may hold their breath for a number of rounds equal to twice their {@characteristic Brawn||crb} and only suffer 2 wounds for each round they are exposed to {@rule vacuum||crb}.

talent.name: Fires of Conviction
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Gashlai} or a {@archetype N'orr} or have allegiance to the {@rule Yin Brotherhood}, the {@rule Argent Flight}, or the {@rule The Keleres of the Council|Keleres} to benefit from this talent.} Your character rerolls failed fear checks.

talent.name: Hand on the Throttle
description: Once per round while controlling a vehicle that requires the {@skill Driving||crb} or {@skill Piloting||crb} skill to direct, your character may use this talent to increase or decrease its speed by 1, to a minimum of 0 or a maximum of the vehicle's max speed.

talent.name: Historical Record
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Winnu} or have allegiance to the {@rule Empyrean} or {@rule The Nomad} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session before making a knowledge skill check or {@skill Astrocartography||crb} check, your character may use this talent to succeed on the check with {@symbols sss}.

talent.name: Life on the Streets
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Skulduggery||crb} or {@skill Deception||crb} as a career skill. In addition, when using one of these skills to obtain wealth (whether by stealing something, lying about the worth of an item, or other duplicitous means), your character may spend {@symbols aa} to heal 3 strain.

talent.name: Nocturnal Upbringing
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Perception||crb} or {@skill Stealth||crb} as a career skill. In addition, your character may remove {@dice setback} added to their checks due to {@rule concealment (darkness, smoke, and intervening terrain)|darkness|crb}.

talent.name: Null Gravity Adept
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Athletics||crb} or {@skill Coordination||crb} as a career skill. In addition, when making a check using one of these skills in a {@rule gravity|zero-gravity|crb} environment, your character may spend {@symbols aa} to heal 3 strain.

talent.name: Sagacious Instruction
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Astrocartography||crb} or any one knowledge skill as a career skill. In addition, when making a skill check to navigate to an unknown system or to learn new information, your character may spend {@symbols aa} to heal 3 strain.

talent.name: Skilled Mechanic
description: When your character makes a check to repair hull trauma or system strain, they repair 1 additional hull trauma or system strain per rank of Skilled Mechanic.

talent.name: Subtle
description: When making a social skill check, your character can use this talent to spend {@symbols a} to convey to one other character a simple message that has nothing to do with what your character is actually saying. The means by which you convey this message is up to you and your GM, but could include body language, subtle gestures, double entendres, or references to shared experiences.

talent.name: War Veteran
description: When you take this talent, your character gains {@skill Athletics||crb} or {@skill Resilience||crb} as a career skill. In addition, when healing strain after a combat encounter, your character may spend {@symbols aa} to heal 3 strain.

talent.name: Where Did I Put That?
description: Once per session, your character may use this talent to make an {@difficulty average|cool}. If successful, they may choose one item that has been lost, misplaced, or left behind during a previous encounter and then find the item on their person or in an easily accessible location

talent.name: Xenoreader
description: When you purchase this talent for your character, choose one of the following five categories: mammalian, aquatic, insectoid, reptilian, or anomaly (species that do not fit into one of the other categories). When your character makes a social skill check targeting a member of the chosen category, add {@symbols aa} to the results.
Each additional time you purchase this talent for your character, you may choose one additional category.

talent.name: Aethersprite
description: Once per encounter, if your character has access to a computer network, they may use this talent to make an {@difficulty average|computers}. If successful, they reduce the difficulty of all further {@skill Computers||crb} and {@skill Skulduggery||crb} checks to use or manipulate the system or linked subsystems (such as electronic locks on doors) by 1 for the remainder of the encounter. If this would reduce a check's difficulty to {@difficulty simple}, the character can choose instead to succeed without making the check.
Any {@symbols d} from this or subsequent checks that involve the system must be spent to alert the system's controllers to your character's intrusion.

talent.name: Angle the Shields
description: While piloting a starship of silhouette 4 or greater, your character may make a {@difficulty hard|operating} to use this talent. If they succeed, their starship suffers system strain no greater than their ranks in this talent, and until the end of their next turn, whenever their starship is targeted by a combat check, remove {@dice setback} from the dice pool equal to the system strain suffered and add an equal number of {@symbols f} to the results.

talent.name: Called Shot
description: When your character uses the aim maneuver to target a specific item carried by an opponent or a specific part of an opponent (see page 99 of the {@title Genesys} Core Rulebook), they do not add any {@dice setback} to the check as a part of performing the maneuver.

talent.name: Chameleon Infiltration
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Yssaril} or have allegiance to the {@rule Yssaril Tribes} to benefit from this talent.} When your character makes a {@skill Stealth||crb} check, they may use this talent and spend all {@symbols a} generated by the check to add an equal number of {@symbols a} to the results of the next combat check they make during the current encounter.

talent.name: Combined Arms
description: While your character is engaged with an enemy, your GM or fellow players may not spend {@symbols d} to cause your character to be hit by an ally's ranged attack.

talent.name: Driven to Succeed
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Human} or {@archetype Winnu} or have allegiance to the {@rule Federation of Sol} or the {@rule Winnu} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session, your character may spend {@symbols aa} or {@symbols t} from any check they make to use this talent to move up to two Story Points from the GM pool to the players' pool.

talent.name: Friends in Low Places
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Saar} or have allegiance to the {@rule Mentak Coalition}, the {@rule Clan of Saar}, or {@rule The Nomad} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session when on a populated world, your character may make an {@difficulty easy|streetwise} to use this talent. If they succeed, they obtain one item with a rarity no greater than twice the number of {@symbols s} scored on the check, or they obtain an equivalent service from a pirate or pirate crew.
If the check generates {@symbols h} or {@symbols d}, your character must pay the cost of the item or service within one week of obtaining it.

talent.name: Gunslinger Diplomacy
description: If your character is armed, they may use this talent to conspicuously display their weapon and add {@symbols ssh} to the results of the next social skill check they make this turn. This may have additional narrative repercussions at your GM's discretion.

talent.name: Inspiration
description: Once per encounter, you may spend a Story Point to have your character use this talent to target another character within hearing range, and tell them to perform a specific task. If your character knows the target's Strength or Desire Motivation, the target may reroll up to three dice of their choice during the next check they make to perform that task during the current encounter.
This talent does not force the target to perform the designated task (it simply benefits them if they do so). In addition, the target becomes less hostile toward your character in the future.

talent.name: Leverage
description: Once per encounter, you may spend a Story Point to have your character use this talent to target another character within hearing range. If your character knows the target's Flaw or Fear Motivation, the target must spend their next turn performing one action of your character's choice. If this occurs during a narrative encounter, this can be a single discrete task instead.

At your GM's discretion, certain actions or tasks may be too unrealistic for the target to perform (such as harming themself or betraying a beloved family member). In addition, the target becomes more hostile toward your character in the future.

talent.name: Long Game
description: When your character purchases this talent, they increase the number of benchmarks they need to complete their current agenda and any future agendas they choose by 2 (see page 64). When they complete an agenda, they double the received rewards (if the rewards are difficult to quantify, your GM determines what an appropriate increase is).
The rest of the party does not double any XP rewards they receive when your character completes their agenda.

talent.name: Overheat
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Hylar} or {@archetype Gashlai} or have allegiance to the {@rule Embers of Muaat} or the {@rule Universities of Jol-Nar} to benefit from this talent.} When making a check while using a piece of equipment (such as operating a vehicle, searching with a scanner, or attacking with a weapon), your character may use this talent to add {@symbols sa} to the results. If they do so, after the check is resolved, the equipment becomes damaged one step (from undamaged to minor, from minor to moderate, from moderate to major, or from major to destroyed; see page 89 of the Core Rulebook). If the equipment is a part of a vehicle, the vehicle suffers 2 system strain instead.

talent.name: Precision Strike
description: When making a {@skill Brawl||crb} or {@skill Melee||crb} combat check, your character may use this talent to remove a number of {@dice boost} from the dice pool no greater than their ranks in Precision Strike and suffer 1 strain per {@dice boost} removed, then add an equal number of {@symbols s} to the results of the check.

talent.name: Shepherding Command
description: {@i Your character must be an {@archetype Xxcha} or a {@archetype Titan} or have allegiance to the {@rule Titans of Ul} or the {@rule Xxcha Kingdom} to benefit from this talent.} Once per encounter when an ally within short range is targeted by an attack, your character may reduce the damage dealt by that attack by your character's ranks in {@skill Leadership||crb} before the damage is reduced by soak.

talent.name: Sneak Attack
description: When your character makes a {@skill Melee||crb} check, they use {@characteristic Cunning||crb} instead of {@characteristic Brawn||crb}. If they add their {@characteristic Brawn||crb} rating to a weapon's base damage, they add their {@characteristic Cunning||crb} rating instead.

talent.name: Sound Investments
description: At the beginning of each game session, your character receives aurei equal to their ranks in Sound Investments times 100.

How your character earns this money is up to you and your GM and could represent actual business investments, an inheritance, a legal or illegal side business, or even bribes or blackmail money. Your GM can also decide that the current events of the adventure may make those funds temporarily unavailable.

talent.name: Sustained Fire
description: After making a {@skill Ranged (Light)||crb}, {@skill Ranged (Heavy)||crb}, or {@skill Gunnery||crb} check, your character may use this talent to spend {@symbols aaa} or {@symbols t} to add {@symbols a} equal to their ranks in Sustained Fire to the results of all {@skill Ranged (Light)||crb}, {@skill Ranged (Heavy)||crb}, or {@skill Gunnery||crb} checks they make against the same target until the end of the current encounter.
The check does not have to be successful to use this talent.

talent.name: Aethersprite (Improved)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Aethersprite} talent to benefit from this talent.} If your character made a successful check to use the {@talent Aethersprite} talent during the current encounter, you may spend a Story Point to have your character use this talent to make themselves and up to five allies invisible to any electronic sensors for a number of rounds equal to your character's ranks in Computers.

This works on any electronic monitoring or surveillance systems, such as cameras, heat and motion sensors, and even microradar pulses. It also affects any nonsentient drones or robots that are linked with the network affected by {@talent Aethersprite}.

talent.name: Ccrysusian Methodology
description: Once per session when your character is targeted by a social skill check, they may use this talent to reduce any strain they suffer by an amount equal to their ranks in {@skill Negotiation||crb}, to a minimum amount of strain of 1.
Each additional rank of Ccrysusian Methodology increases the number of times your character can use this talent each session by 1.

talent.name: Deliberate Tactics
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Titan} or an {@archetype Xxcha} or have allegiance to the {@rule Titans of Ul} or the {@rule Xxcha Kingdom} to benefit from this talent.} During a combat encounter, your character may choose to take either no maneuvers or no actions during their turn to use this talent. If they do, they reduce all strain suffered to 0 (both voluntary and involuntary) until the start of their next turn and add {@symbols aa} to combat checks they make until the start of their next turn.

talent.name: Dual Blow
description: When resolving a combined check to attack with two weapons in melee or ranged combat, your character may suffer 3 strain to use this talent to hit with the secondary weapon (instead of spending {@symbols aa}).

talent.name: Expert Gunner
description: When your character makes a {@skill Gunnery||crb} check, they may suffer 3 strain to use this talent to reduce the number of {@symbols a} needed to activate any of their weapon's item qualities by 1, to a minimum of 1, until the end of the turn.

talent.name: Expert Scrapper
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Saar} or have allegiance to the {@rule Clan of Saar} or the {@rule Mentak Coalition} to benefit from this talent.} Once per encounter while engaged with a vehicle, your character can use this talent to make a {@skill Mechanics||crb} check with a difficulty equal to the vehicle's silhouette. The vehicle suffers 1 hull trauma per {@symbols s}, and one Critical Hit per {@symbols aaa} or {@symbols t}.

talent.name: Master of the Blade
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Hacan}, a {@archetype Letnev}, or a {@archetype N'orr} or have allegiance to the {@rule Sardakk N'orr} to benefit from this talent.} Your character adds {@symbols f} to the results of all combat checks targeting them while they are wielding a Melee weapon and engaged with multiple enemies (a single minion group counts as multiple enemies for the purposes of this talent).

talent.name: Mercantile Savant
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Naaz-Rokha} or a {@archetype Hacan} or have allegiance to the {@rule Emirates of Hacan} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session, you may spend a Story Point to reduce the price of one item or service that your character is attempting to purchase by 50% or increase the monetary value of a mission reward by 50%.
The specifics of how your character accomplishes this is up to you and your GM but could include negotiation, calling in favors, or even intimidation.

talent.name: Mind Bender
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Druaa} or have allegiance to the {@rule Naalu Collective} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session, your character may spend a Story Point to use this talent to make an {@b opposed {@skill Discipline||crb} versus {@skill Vigilance||crb} check} targeting one creature within medium range. If successful, your character may cause the target to adopt an emotional state of your character's choice for the remainder of the current encounter (or one hour in narrative gameplay). Your character may spend {@symbols aa} or {@symbols t} to have the target unquestionably believe one piece of information of your character's choice for the remainder of the encounter, even if it is untrue. (Your character may do this multiple times, and they may even do this if the check fails.)

At the end of the current encounter, at your GM's discretion the target may or may not continue to believe any information inserted in their mind, depending on how outlandish it is in the face of reality. However, if the check fails with {@symbols hhh} or {@symbols d}, the target knows that someone attempted to manipulate their mind.

talent.name: Not Even in Death
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype N'orr} or a {@archetype Shikrai} or have allegiance to the {@rule Argent Flight} or the {@rule Sardakk N'orr} to benefit from this talent.} When your character would be incapacitated by suffering wounds that exceed their wound threshold, you may spend a Story Point to have your character use this talent to immediately make a combat check with a weapon they are currently wielding.

talent.name: Primacy
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Letnev} or a {@archetype Winnu} or have allegiance to the {@rule Barony of Letnev} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session when making a skill check not linked to {@characteristic Presence||crb}, your character may use this talent to upgrade the ability of the check a number of times equal to their {@characteristic Presence||crb} rating.

talent.name: Raptor's Flight
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Druaa} or {@archetype Shikrai} or have allegiance to the {@rule Argent Flight} to benefit from this talent.} Once per encounter while piloting a vehicle, your character may make a {@difficulty hard|piloting} to use this talent. If successful, your character may change the speed of the vehicle they are piloting to any other speed the vehicle is capable of reaching. Your character can also spend {@symbols aa} from the results to increase the difficulty of combat checks targeting their vehicle by 1 and decrease the difficulty of combat checks made by themself or other occupants of their vehicle by 1 until the start of your character's next turn.

talent.name: Solo Flight
description: Before making an {@skill Operating||crb} check, your character may use this talent to increase the difficulty of the check by 1 and use the {@skill Piloting||crb} skill to make the check, instead of the {@skill Operating||crb} skill. In addition, if the vehicle requires multiple pilots, your character may operate the vehicle alone when they use this talent.

talent.name: Spec Ops Elimination
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Human} or {@archetype Yssaril} or have allegiance to the {@rule Federation of Sol} to benefit from this talent.} After your character makes a successful combat check against a target who is unaware of their presence, your character may use this talent to inflict a Critical Injury on the target without spending {@symbols a} or {@symbols t}. Your character may still inflict only one Critical Injury per hit, but they may spend additional {@symbols a} equal to the attack's Critical rating or {@symbols t} to increase the severity of the Critical Injury as normal.

talent.name: University Training
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Hylar} or have allegiance to the {@rule Universities of Jol-Nar} to benefit from this talent.} Once per encounter, your character may use this talent to make a check with a skill that is linked to {@characteristic Intellect||crb} as a maneuver, rather than an action, and add {@symbols s} to the results.

talent.name: Aethersprite (Supreme)
description: {@i Your character must have purchased the {@talent Aethersprite} talent to benefit from this talent.} If your character made a successful {@talent Aethersprite} check during the current encounter, your character may use this talent to make a {@difficulty hard|computers}. If they succeed, they falsify a major distraction in the system. The particulars of the distraction are up to you and your GM, but they should be significant enough that any opponents ignore your characters and leave key installations unguarded or unlocked as they work furiously to deal with the distraction or flee for their lives. (Examples might include a major reactor meltdown, an enemy battlefleet entering local space, or poisonous nerve gas being leaked into the facility.)

At your GM's discretion, certain actions that your character undertakes may cause opponents to attempt to deal with them, such as actively attacking an opponent or shouting that your character is the one who initiated the distraction.

talent.name: Beam Fighter
description: While using a beam weapon with the {@quality Pierce||crb} item quality, your character may use this talent to cause the weapon to lose that quality. If they do, after your character makes a ranged combat check before the end of their turn, they may assign a number of additional hits from their weapon equal to the value of the {@quality Pierce||crb} item quality that the weapon lost. Each hit deals damage equal to the weapon's base damage plus the number of {@symbols s} scored on the check.
Each hit must be assigned to a different target within short range of another target (each minion in a minion group counts as a target for the purposes of this talent).

talent.name: Combat Command
description: When your character makes a check to {@rule determine Initiative||crb} order (as described on page 95 of the {@title Genesys} Core Rulebook), they may make a {@difficulty simple|leadership} instead of using {@skill Cool||crb} or {@skill Vigilance||crb}. If your character does so, they may spend {@symbols t} from the check to add {@symbols s} to the results of all allies' checks made during the first round of the combat encounter.

Your GM may determine that you cannot use this talent if your character is in no logical position to give orders, such as if they have no means of communicating with allies or are working with individuals who have no interest in listening to your character.

talent.name: Dormant Personality Overlay
description: When your character purchases this talent, select three skills that your character has one or no ranks in. Once per session, you may spend a Story Point to have your character use this talent. Until the end of the current encounter, they count as having four ranks in each of the selected skills and one fewer rank in all other skills. They also suffer 1 strain at the beginning of each of their turns. If they are incapacitated, the effects of this talent end.

At your discretion, your character may also undergo some narrative personality shifts, such as not recognizing friends and family, behaving coldly and logically instead of in a friendly and relaxed manner, or constantly muttering a coded phrase under their breath.

talent.name: Fly Quiet
description: Once per encounter while controlling a spaceship, your character may use this talent to make a {@difficulty hard|piloting or operating} (depending on the skill needed to control the vehicle). If the check is successful, the ship vanishes from sensors and cannot be located unless it fires weapons, broadcasts a signal, or performs another activity that reasonably allows others to spot it, or unless an opponent aboard another starship with sensors makes a successful {@b opposed {@skill Computers||crb} versus {@skill Piloting||crb} or {@skill Operating||crb} check} targeting your character

talent.name: Future Sight
description: {@i Your character must have allegiance to {@rule The Nomad} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session, after performing an action (and seeing the results of any check made as a part of that action), your character may use this talent to cancel the results of that action and perform a different action instead. (Narratively, the first action did not occur, and your character only performed the second action.)

talent.name: Multitasking
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Naaz-Rokha} or have allegiance to the {@rule Naaz-Rokha Alliance} to benefit from this talent.} Once per encounter, your character may use this talent to exchange two maneuvers for an action. This allows your character to perform two actions during a single turn.

Your character must have two maneuvers available to exchange to use this talent. This means that unless your character has two free maneuvers during their turn, they must obtain a second maneuver by spending {@symbols aa} or suffering strain.

talent.name: Pommel Smash
description: After making a Melee combat check with a weapon that requires two hands to wield, your character may suffer 3 strain to use this talent to cause one engaged opponent of silhouette 2 or less to become staggered (unable to perform actions) until the end of your character's next turn.

talent.name: Against All Odds
description: Once per session, after your character makes a check, they may use this talent to select one of the following types of results: {@symbols f}, {@symbols h}, or {@symbols d}. If they select {@symbols f}, they then remove all {@symbols f} and add an equal number of {@symbols s} to the results. If they select {@symbols h}, they then remove all {@symbols h} and add an equal number of {@symbols a} to the results. If they select {@symbols d}, they then remove all {@symbols d} and add an equal number of {@symbols t} to the results.
As part of using this talent, you must describe the awe-inspiring way in which your character overcomes any obstacles present in order to perform this feat.

talent.name: Integral Weapon
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Titan} to benefit from this talent.} When you select this talent, choose one of the following weapons: an {@gear integral particle beam} or an {@gear integral grav-field} for one fist. Your character is equipped with the weapon you choose.

Either weapon requires one free hand to use (as it is a part of your character's palm or hand). It cannot be disarmed or damaged, but a Critical Injury that affects your character's arm may cause it to become unusable temporarily or permanently at your GM's discretion.

talent.name: Mind Breaker
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Druaa} or have allegiance to the {@rule Naalu Collective} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session, your character may spend a Story Point to use this talent to make a {@difficulty hard|discipline}. Whether the check succeeds or fails, all living opponents within medium range suffer strain equal to your character's {@characteristic Willpower||crb} rating. For every {@symbols s}, one opponent of your character's choice within medium range suffers a Compromised Critical Injury. Your character may spend {@symbols a} to increase the strain suffered by all opponents by 1 per {@symbols a} spent.

talent.name: Overwatch
description: Once per round when an opponent attacks an ally who is within long range of your character, you may spend one Story Point and {@symbols h} or {@symbols d} to have your character use this talent to automatically hit the opponent with a ranged weapon your character is wielding, if the opponent is within the weapon's range. The hit deals the weapon's base damage plus additional damage equal to your character's ranks in the skill used to wield the weapon.

talent.name: Remote Personal Wormhole
description: {@i Your character must be a {@archetype Creuss} or have allegiance to the {@rule Ghosts of Creuss} to benefit from this talent.} Once per session, your character may use this talent to instantly teleport to another location that they can see or have previously visited. If the location is within extreme range, they do not have to make a skill check. If the location is beyond extreme range, your character must make a {@difficulty hard|discipline} when they use this talent. They may teleport up to 100 kilometers per {@symbols s}, or spend {@symbols t} to be able to teleport up to 1,000 kilometers per {@symbols s} instead.

If your character teleports 100 kilometers or more, they are staggered for a number of rounds equal to the number of kilometers teleported divided by 10 (rounding up). They may spend {@symbols a} to reduce the number of rounds they are staggered by one per {@symbols a} spent.

talent.name: Void Baron
description: After making a {@skill Piloting||crb} check, your character may spend {@symbols aa} or {@symbols t} from the results to use this talent to make a combat check as a maneuver.

vehicle.name: Personal Transport
description: No matter the culture, people wish to travel farther and faster than they can walk, crawl, or slither. Whether the means of conveyance is wheels, tracks, hovering grav-fields, or even sets of mechanical legs, most civilians move around via some form of personal transport vehicle. Roadways and skylanes are filled with one-person monorides, family-carrying carrums, and cargo haulers of various sizes.

description.title: Alternate Variants
entries: The personal transport vehicle characteristics represent the basic carrum model of civilian transports. For other vehicles, make the following modifications to the vehicle characteristics.

entries.title: {@vehicle Personal Transport (Monoride)|Monoride}

vehicle.name: Personal Transport (Monoride)
description: No matter the culture, people wish to travel farther and faster than they can walk, crawl, or slither. Whether the means of conveyance is wheels, tracks, hovering grav-fields, or even sets of mechanical legs, most civilians move around via some form of personal transport vehicle. Roadways and skylanes are filled with one-person monorides, family-carrying carrums, and cargo haulers of various sizes.

vehicle.name: Rambler

abilities.name: All-Terrain
abilities.description: When making a {@skill Driving||crb} check to direct the vehicle, your character may remove {@dice setback|2} added to the check due to terrain.

description: "Rambler" is a colloquial term for any lightly armed and armored fighting vehicles. They are designed to deliver soldiers to the battlefield and support them with heavy weapons. Most rely on six to eight oversized wheels, but some use tracks or even articulated legs. Not as hardy as tanks or mechs, ramblers are vulnerable to most vehicle and heavy infantry weapons. Even with this relative fragility, most troopers would gladly traverse the battlefield in a rambler rather than doing it on foot.
Ramblers are often used by Keleres as their main mode of ground transportation, especially when traversing the wildernesses of far-flung worlds or while in hostile territory.

vehicle.name: Light Mech

abilities.name: All Terrain
abilities.description: When making a {@skill Driving||crb} check to direct the vehicle, your character may remove {@dice setback|2} added to the check due to terrain.

description: "Mech" is a colloquial term for armored military vehicles. Most are bipedal or quadrupedal, but some have dozens of legs, while a few utilize other means of locomotion, such as grav-pods or tracks. High-speed light mechs serve as scouts, flankers, and pursuers. Lightly armed and armored, they are still able to bring notable firepower to different points on a battle line at a moment's notice.

entries.title: {@vehicle Light mech (Sardakk N'orr Valkyrie Exoskeleton)|Sardakk N'orr Valkyrie Exoskeleton}
entries: Increase speed to 4; reduce hull trauma threshold to 8; increase price to 25,000 aurei; replace arm-mounted burster grenade launcher with twin boosted plasma projectors ({@skill Gunnery||crb}; Damage 8; Critical 3; Range [Medium]; {@quality Blast|Blast 8|crb}, {@quality Burn|Burn 4|crb}, {@quality Linked|Linked 1|crb}, {@quality Personal Scale||crb}).

Allied vehicles or characters within medium range of this vehicle gain defense 2.

description: While light mechs scout enemy positions and deal with flanking maneuvers, heavy mechs are built to assault main battle lines. Often ten to fifteen meters high, these colossi stride across the battlefield like metallic gods, raining fire and death on those who dare to face them. As with light mechs, most heavy mechs are bipedal or quadrupedal, but some civilizations build ones with different locomotive systems.
